unnormalised: My cousin, Priya, always had a knack for numbers. Growing up in a small town in Bihar, she used to manage the family's kirana store accounts with an old calculator and a worn-out ledger. I remember her frustration when customers would haggle over prices, down to the last ₹5. Little did we know, that skill would lead her to the world of fintech.
normalised: My cousin, Priya, always had a knack for numbers. Growing up in a small town in Bihar, she used to manage the family's kirana store accounts with an old calculator and a worn-out ledger. I remember her frustration when customers would haggle over prices, down to the last rupee five. Little did we know, that skill would lead her to the world of fintech.

unnormalised: It all started when Priya moved to Bangalore after getting a scholarship to study computer science. She was fascinated by the power of technology and how it could solve real-world problems. One day, she stumbled upon a news article about UPI and the digital payments revolution in India. Suddenly, all those hours spent calculating interest rates and managing cash flow in the kirana store felt relevant.
normalised: It all started when Priya moved to Bangalore after getting a scholarship to study computer science. She was fascinated by the power of technology and how it could solve real-world problems. One day, she stumbled upon a news article about U-P-I and the digital payments revolution in India. Suddenly, all those hours spent calculating interest rates and managing cash flow in the kirana store felt relevant.

unnormalised: She became obsessed with the idea of building fintech solutions for small businesses, the ones that were still relying on outdated methods. Her initial ideas were ambitious - a complete POS system with inventory management and real-time reporting. But she quickly realized that these businesses were often wary of complex tech, requiring significant training.
normalised: She became obsessed with the idea of building fintech solutions for small businesses, the ones that were still relying on outdated methods. Her initial ideas were ambitious - a complete P-O-S system with inventory management and real-time reporting. But she quickly realized that these businesses were often wary of complex tech, requiring significant training.

unnormalised: Then came her Eureka moment during her internship at a small startup. Her boss, Mr. Sharma, mentioned how they struggled with managing vendor payments and reconciliation. That’s when Priya decided to simplify things. She built a lightweight mobile app that allowed small businesses to track payments, send reminders, and generate basic reports.
normalised: Then came her Eureka moment during her internship at a small startup. Her boss, Mister Sharma, mentioned how they struggled with managing vendor payments and reconciliation. That’s when Priya decided to simplify things. She built a lightweight mobile app that allowed small businesses to track payments, send reminders, and generate basic reports.

unnormalised: Getting her first client was tougher than she imagined. Convincing mom-and-pop stores to trust a new app with their hard-earned money wasn't easy. But Priya persisted. She started with her uncle’s hardware store in Patna, offering the app for free in exchange for feedback. Slowly, word spread. The app, which she affectionately called "LekhaMitra," started gaining traction.

She started with her uncle’s hardware store in Patna, offering the app for free in exchange for feedback. Slowly, word spread. The app, which she affectionately called "LekhaMitra," started gaining traction.

unnormalised: Now, LekhaMitra has over 5000 users across Bihar and Jharkhand. Priya’s even added new features, like integration with Bharat BillPay and automated GST calculations. Last month, she secured ₹1 crore in seed funding from a local angel investor. I saw her at Diwali last week, and she was glowing. She told me she plans to expand LekhaMitra across North India and onboard 10,000 businesses by Q2 2025.

She told me she plans to expand LekhaMitra across North India and onboard ten thousand businesses by Q two two thousand and twenty five.

unnormalised: Looking back, it’s amazing to see how far Priya has come. From managing accounts in a small kirana store to building a successful fintech startup, she's truly a testament to the power of hard work, ingenuity, and a little bit of tech magic. And it all started with a ₹5 argument and a worn-out ledger.
